That's your decision. (Stubs out cigarette.) But when they storm the flat, throw  yourself out of die window - don't  let them get you alive. I have  poison on me, they won't get me  alive either!

And he goes. Szpilman listens to his footsteps clattering down the stairs. He sees the cigarette stub, takes it, lights it, coughs,  smokes awkwardly.  Later:  Szpilman hears a car engine and the screech of brakes. He tenses. German voices shouting and their heavy footsteps  on the stairs. He goes to the window, opens it. He gets a chair, places  it sideways in front of the window to make a step. He's  working out how best to throw himself out. He leans against the wall near the door and waits..  Slamming of doors, German shouts, a scream. Szpilman steels himself, ready to jump. Again footsteps on the stairs, but this time descending. door slams. He cautiously goes to the window and looks out.
In the street below, he sees SS men escorting two prisone and shoving into a car. The car speeds off. The street is empty.
Snow. Howling wind. Szpilman lies on the divan. He is cold, unshaven, hair  filthy and long. He manages to rise.

A mess. Szpilman goes into the kitchen. From a bread tin  he takes a small, flat greaseproof paper parcel and unwra it. A slice of bread, stale and mouldy. He tries to bite  it but can't. He finds a knife and tries to chop a piece  off the bread but knocks the bread tin, which falls to th floor with a clatter.  He continues to try to cut the bread, when there's a loud hammering on the front door. Szpilman stiffens.
The hammering continues as Szpilman stumbles into the roo looks around, confused, not knowing what to do. From the other side of the door female voices, words  indistinct, and then:
Open this door at once, or we'll  call the police!

He is galvanised into action, puts on a crumpled jacket,  grabs his tattered coat and scarf, collects up a few of  his things, stuffs them into a paper bag.  The hammering stops. Szpilman cautiously approaches the  door, listens, then opens it quietly and slips out.
He slips out of the flat, goes to the stairs and stops  dead. KITTY, young and fierce, stands on the stairs,  blocking his way.
Are you from the flat in there?  You're not registered.
It belongs to a friend of mine. I  came to visit but I must have just  missed him.
(shouting) Have you got your identity card?  Let me see your identity card!
Szpilman hesitates; she shouts more loudly.
I want to see your identity card!
On various floors, doors open, tenants put their heads ou to see what's going on. Summoning all his strength, Szpilman makes a dash for it, pushing past Kitty.
(screeching) He's a Jew! He's a Jew! Stop the  Jew! Don't let him out!
Szpilman clatters down the stairs, reaches the ground-flo landing. Another woman tries to bar his way but he pushes past her and out of the house.
Heavy snow. Szpilman stumbles into the street and runs. H darts down a side street.

Szpilman lurches into the narrow street. No one about. He stops, almost collapses, but manages to keep hold of  himself. He puts on his coat and wraps the scarf round hi neck. He leans up against a wall. He removes a shoe and takes out the scrap of paper  Gebczynski gave him. He reads it.

Szpilman drags himself along, trudging through snow and  slush. Passers-by give him a wide berth. He tries to walk normally, with dignity, but he's weak and slips, and find the going hard. He comes to a villa.
He goes to the front door, rings the bell and waits.
(from behind the  door) Yes?
Mr Gebczynski sent me.
The door opens and Dorota stands there. She is pregnant.  They stand for a moment staring at each other.
(a whisper) Wladyslaw Szpilman.
Dorota.
Come in! come in!
Szpilman follows Dorota into the living room.
Sit.
I'm sorry - I was given this  address. I'm looking for a Mr-- (He checks the scrap  of paper.') -- a Mr Dzikiewicz.
(nodding) Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband.
Szpilman sits down slowly.
I need help.
He'll be back before curfew.
I've been in hiding. I need  somewhere to stay.
He'll be here soon.
Awkward silence. He gazes at her. She looks away.
How long have you been married?
Just over a year.
He nods. Brief silence.
And how's Yurek?
Dead.
Again, the awkward silence.
When's your baby due?
Christmas. (A pause.) This is not a good time to have  children. But then...
The door opens and Michal Dzikiewicz enters. He sees  Szpilman and stops. Szpilman stands.
This is my husband. Wladyslaw  Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent  him.
Oh, yes. I remember.
He shakes hands with Szpilman.
Mr Gebczynski said to contact you  only in an emergency, but...
Don't worry now. We can't move you  tonight.
Szpilman, dizzy, leans on the table for support.
You'll sleep on the sofa.
He and Dorota look at him.
Excuse me, could I have a piece of  bread?
Yes, of course, we'll eat.

Szpilman asleep on the sofa. The sound of a cello. He ope his eyes. Listens. He swings his legs off the sofa, stands, and crosses to a door. Quietly, he opens it a little. Szpilman and his POV - another room. Dorota, partially turned away from him, plays Bach on the cello. Szpilman watches her and listens.
A padlock being unlocked. Then, a key is inserted into th Yale lock, turned, and the door opens. Michal and Szpilman on the landing, enter the flat.
A large room, sparsely furnished but with an upright pian and a bed. Michal carries a bag of provisions and puts them on a tab while Szpilman goes immediately to the window and looks  out.

There are views of the city, but in the street below,  opposite, is a hospital and, on the corner, a building  flying a Nazi flag and guarded by a sentry, standing at  his sentry-box.   Michal comes up behind Szpilman.

(in whisper) You're in a very German area. The  building opposite is a hospital,  taking in wounded from the Russian  front. Next door is the  Schutzpolizei. It's the safest  place to be. Right in the centre  of the lion's den.
Michal makes for the door.
I'll be locking you in. No one  knows you're here. So keep as quiet  as possible.

He nods and goes. The sound of the padlock closing. Szpil takes in the room. He sees the piano, is still for a mome then goes to it.  He sits on the piano stool and adjusts its height. He ope the lid. A cloth covers the keys. He removes the cloth. H gazes lovingly at the keyboard. He flexes his fingers. Then, without touching the keys, his fingers floating jus above them, he plays. Silently. Passionately.
Snow falling.
Szpilman alert, hearing the padlock being unlocked and  then iheYdle. The door opens and Michal enters, accompani by a man, aged about thirty, Szalas, confident, a little  brash.  In whispers:
All well?
Thank you.
This is Antek Szalas.
Szalas and Szpilman shake hands.
He's going to look after you. I've  given him a second key. He'll bring  you food. See that you're all right.  He's with the underground, a good  man.
Szalas produces a quarter bottle of vodka, thumps the bac of the bottle so that the cork flies out. He finds glasse and pours. While he does all this:
You don't remember me, Mr. Szpilman?
No, I don't think so?
Warsaw Radio. I was a technician.  I saw you almost every day.
Sorry, I don't remember.
Doesn't matter. You've nothing to  worry about. I'll visit often.
And you'll be pleased to hear the  Allies are bombing Germany night  after night - Cologne, Hamburg,  Berlin.
And the Russians are really giving  them hell. It's the beginning of  the end.
He gives the others their vodka.
Let's hope so. I don't know when  I'll see you again?
They clink glasses and drink.
Summer. Trees in leaf. Comings and goings at the Schutzpolizei building. And an  ambulance draws up at the hospital, disgorging a couple o stretcher cases, who are carried inside.

very weak and his skin yellowish, drops four beans into  boiling water.  The Sound of the padlock being opened. Szpilman hurries to see the door open and Szalas enter  with a small and grinning cheerfully. In whispers:
Still alive then, are you? Here.  Sausage. Bread.
He hands over the package. You still got that vodka?  Szpilman stares at the package.
How long is this meant to last?
Szalas shrugs, finds the vodka, pours two glasses
think I've got jaundice.
He unwraps the package to reveal sausage and bread. He  takes a bite of sausage, chewing deliberately, slowly.
You don't want to worry about that.  My grandfather was jilted by his  girl friend when he got jaundice. (chuckles.) In my opinion, jaundice is not  very serious. Drink up.
Why didn't you come sooner? It's  been over two weeks.
Szalas goes to the window, looks out.
Problems. Money. I've got to raise  money to buy the food. I need things  to sell, it' s not easy.
Szpilman thinks for a moment, then takes off his wristwat hands it to Szalas.
Sell this. Food's more important  than time.
Szalas pockets the watch, makes for the door, stops.
Oh, yes. I meant to tell you. The  Allies have landed in France. The  Russians'll be here soon. They'll  beat the shit out of the Germans.  Any day now.
He grins, downs Szpilman's vodka, gives a mock salute and goes.  Hie padlock is locked on the other side. Szpilman  enjoys his sausage.

Sunshine floods in through the windows.  Szpilman lies inert on the bed, weak, starving, ill.  The sound of the padlock. He doesn't stir. Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter, come to the bed.  In whispers:
Wladek? Wladek! (to Michal) I knew it, I knew this would happen!
Szpilman barely has strength to open his eyes and focus o them. He mutters incoherently.
I'm going to get a doctor.
You can't, it's too dangerous.
I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust  him.
Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's  a pediatrician.
He's still a doctor.
She starts for the door.
No, you stay, I'll go.
He leaves. The padlock sound.  Dorota goes to the kitchen, wets a towel, comes back to  the bed, kneels it, places the towel on Szpilman's brow.  He focuses on her, smiles.
We came to say goodbye. We're going  to stay with my mother in Otwock.The  baby's already there. It's safer.  There's talk that the uprising  will begin any day now.
Szpilman suddenly winces with pain.
That man Szalas should be shot.  He's been collecting money on your  behalf all over Warsaw. Apparently,  people gave generously. So he  collected a tidy sum. He told us  he was visiting you daily.
She looks at him; barely audible.
Oh God!
Later:  Szpilman looks up at Dr Luczak, who has a stethoscope in  his ears. Dorota and Michal stand behind him.
Acute inflammation of the gall  bladder. Liver the size of a  football. But he'll live. I'll try  to get hold of some levulose, but  it's not easy.
Can you visit him again?
Who knows?
Doctor, thank you.
Don't speak. Rest.
The Doctor and Michal leave his line of vision.  Dorota moves in beside him.
Michal brought food. I'll prepare  something now for you, then we  must go.
Szpilman tries again to say something, but he can't, just lies there, distressed.

Szpilman looking down from the fourth-floor window.  Peaceful. A few pedestrians. An everyday atmosphere.  At the far end, at the T-junction with a main road, a tra rumbles down the street and comes to a halt, disgorging  passengers on the far side and so out of sight.  The tram continues on its way, now revealing the few  passengers who alighted '97 women, an old man with a stic Last, three young Poles, carrying long objects wrapped in newspaper.   One of the men looks at his watch, glances around, then  suddenly kneels and puts the package he's carrying to his shoulder. The sound of rapid firing, which makes the  newspaper at the end of the packet glow to reveal the bar of a machine gun.  His two companions have also put their packages to their  shoulders and begin shooting, all aiming their fire at th Schutzpolizei building.  The sentry is hit and falls in front of his box.  As if these young men have given a signal, now from all  over the city comes the sound of gunfire.  The pedestrians have scattered except for the old man,  gasping for breath, hobbling on his walking stick, who  eventually manages to disappear inside a building.  Rifle and machine-gun fire from the Schutzpolizei buildin The firing intense. The three young Poles manoeuvre to th corner opposite the Schutzpolizei and toss grenades into  the building.

A battle raging. The Germans firing from the hospital.  The three young Poles have been joined by other fighters  and they the Schutzpolizei building.  Grenades thrown, machine-gun fire exchanged. The sentry box blows up, splinters of wood cascading. A  couple of Poles make a dash for it and enter a building  opposite to the Schutzpolizei.

Szpilman watching from his window, looks in the opposite  direction and sees smoke rising. When he turns back to look towards the T-junction, he see a Panzerfaust anti-tank rocket firer poking out from a  window in the next-door building but on the floor below.  The Panzerfaust fires. The shell hits the hospital.
The city in flames. Sound of firing becoming sporadic, less intense. Isolated explosions.
Szpilman, lying on the bed, staring at the ceiling.
The interior of the Schutzpolizei building burnt to cinde An ambulance is being loaded with patients from the  hospital. A horse-drawn cab rounds a corner and clatters down the  street.

Szpilman at the window, watching. The horse-drawn cab clatters out of his sight. He is abou to draw back when he sees, directly beneath him, a man an woman walking with their hands in the air. Then, a German soldier, pointing his rifle at their backs, appears.  Suddenly, the man and woman begin to run. The man turns and disappears. The woman also turns, but  the German soldier drops to one knee and fires. The woman clutches her stomach, drops slowly to her knees and collapses on the street in an awkward kneeling positi and that's how she remains. Szpilman watches, aghast. Then, he hears voices outside  his door, shouts, footsteps, panic.
He runs to his front door and listens.
(confused) Where? Where? Just get out!  Everywhere! Get out into the street!
More clatter of footsteps. Then:
Get out now! The Germans have  surrounded the building! They're  going to blow us to pieces.
Footsteps descending stairs, more shouts, and:
(further off) Everyone out, please! Leave your  flats at once, please!
Szpilman runs to the door, tries it but it's padlocked an he can't open the door. In panic, he runs back to the window.  His eyes grow wide with terror.

A German tank bringing its gun to bear on the building  next to his. The gun jerks back and there's a great roaring noise.  The whole building shakes. Szpilman reek back, falls, get to his feet and crawls back to the window.  He sees the tank turret swivelling slowly, bringing the  gun to bear directly on a lower floor of his building. Th roaring noise again. A terrific explosion. His windows are shattered. Glass  everywhere. He is thrown back across the room. Smoke begi to billow and fill the room.

Smoke filling the room. Szpilman gets to his knees, peers through the smoke and sees that the wall separating his  apartment from the one next door has been partially  destroyed, with a large hole blasted in it. He stumbles  into the next-door apartment and out of the front door.
Smoke everywhere. Szpilman staggers up to the fifth-floor landing. There's a metal attic door.  Szpilman pushes open the door and steps into the attic.
The roof space with laundry drying on lines. Szpilman ent the attic, closes the door, leans on it.
Fourth floor, Fischke!
He looks round, sees that the roof has been shattered,  leaving a large, jagged gap. He climbs through the gap, o to the roof at the back of the building.
The attic door being kicked in by a German boot.  A German soldier, wearing his gas mask, bayonet fixed,  enters the attic, looks round, sees nothing, then:
At the double, Fischke!
The soldier turns and hurries out.

On the sloping roof, Szpilman clutches the skylight and  has his feet in the roof gutter. He listens - all quiet in the house. And then a bullet ricochets off the tiles beside him.  Szpilman, terrified, drops, involuntarily catching a lowe edge so that his feet dangle above a balcony below. More  shots. He drops on to the balcony and looks back.
Two German soldiers are firing at Szpilman.
Szpilman clambers back into the building through the smas balcony door. A couple of shots dangerously close.
Smoke. Szpilman staggers down the stairs, stumbles over a corpse and almost falls headlong.
The sun is setting. Szpilman crawls into the backyard. He hears German voices shouting commands. He hides behind three garbage bins by  the wall. He waits. Listens.  Silence
Deserted. Buildings on fire but dying out. Corpses in the street, including the woman who was shot, still in her  strange kneeling position.

Szpilman watches from the doorway. Then, dropping down, h crawls across the road on his stomach, threading his way  through the dead bodies, now besieged by flies, and makes for the hospital opposite. German soldiers appear from around a corner. Szpilman  immediately lies still, pretending to be just another  corpse. Flies alight on him. When the Germans pass, he  sets off again.

Dark.  Szpilman crawls into a corner, rests. He's exhaust He tries to take stock of his surroundings. He can make  out the operating table. He manages to drag himself on to it. He lies there, his eyes grow heavy. He sleeps.
German soldiers dragging the corpses into a pile. A sergeant douses the bodies in petrol, then sets them  alight. The bodies burn.

From a shattered window on the first floor, he looks at  the burning bodies. Two German soldiers wander into his eyeline. He draws bac a little but watches them warily.  They sit just beneath him, chatting, and take out their  food-tins, drink coffee and eat bread.
Szpilman wanders down the passage, sees into the wards,  the empty beds, the broken furniture and medical equipmen

Szpilman opens cupboards, drawers, searching, but trying  to be as quiet as possible. He sees the refrigerator, quickly gets to it, pulls open  the door. Empty. He looks around and notices a red fire bucket with a spad and a box of sand next to it. The bucket is full of water covered with an iridescent film and full of dead flies. He drinks as much water as he can without swallowing the  flies and, while he's doing so, he spots a couple of sack He opens the first: potatoes. The second contains barley. He tries to eat the uncooked barley but can't.  Later:  A fire on the floor. Szpilman holds a saucepan over it an is cooking the barley and some potatoes. He manages to  scoop out a spoonful, blows to cool it, then eats.

Szpilman at a window sees autumn leaves thick on the grou And at the end of the street, a line of Poles, some with  their hands in the air, others with hands on heads, being marched away by German soldiers. INT. WARD. RUINED HOSPITAL - DAY. Szpilman lies in bed under several layers of blankets. Ic on the windows. He hears German voices shouting commands. He sits up.

Szpilman gets to a window and looks out. German soldiers with flame-throwers are burning the  buildings opposite. One soldier, with a bucket of white paint and a brush,  numbers the building. Szpilman cranes to see them reach the end of the street,  then cross over and start on the buildings on his side,  working their way towards the hospital. He pulls away and makes for the back of the hospital.
Szpilman goes to a window, jumps out. He twists his ankle He's in pain. He crawls across the back garden and climbs over the wall.
Devastation, not a human being in sight.  Nothing. Emptiness.  He is alone. Szpilman hobbles away.
Cautiously, Szpilman limps towards the villa, a once gran building, but now partly damaged by shell fire.  He makes his way in.

Szpilman enters the hall, still showing signs of its form opulence. I Silent. Ominous. He looks round anxiously, then sees the stairs leading  down to the basement. He hurries towards them and descend

Dark, shadowy. Szpilman comes down a flight of wooden stairs that had  directly into the kitchen. Immediately, he begins to search fractically, opening  cupboards, drawers. He finds a can with a label illustrat pickled cucumbers. Desperately, he searches for something to open it with. He discovers a pair of scales with a variety of weights.  He seizes one of the weights when, very close, he hears  the sound of a car coming to a halt, then the car door  slam, a German voice giving commands. He drops the weight but, holding the tin, he scampers up  the stairs.
Szpilman, clutching the unopened tin, makes his way up th narrow, wooden staircase.
Szpilman, panting heavily, reaches the top floor. He sees a small door, tries it. It opens.

Szpilman enters, closing the small door behind him. He  leans back, resting, recovering. And then he hears from down below a piano playing a  Beethoven piece. After a few bars, the music stops. Szpilman listens  anxiously. Silence. He looks around, finding himself in an attic space filled with junk, a ladder, rotting material, travelling trunks. Last light of day filtering through a dormer window.  There's a ladder leading up to a trapdoor. Szpilman climb the ladder. He crawls into a small empty space. With enormous effort  he pulls up the ladder and closes the trapdoor. Exhausted and trying to catch his breath, he gazes at the unopened tin. He peers through the darkness but sees  nothing. His eyes begin to droop.
Artillery fire. Fires glow on the horizon.
Szpilman wakes suddenly. He listens. Silence but for the  distant gunfire. He sees the unopened tin of pickles, sta at it. He opens the trapdoor.
Szpilman, a shadow, a spectre, creeps down the stairs.

Szpilman has placed the tin and the weight on a shelf and is engrossed in searching again. He finds a pair of chick scissors. Using the weight, he starts to hammer the point of the scissors into the tin making a perforation round  the rim. The tin slips off the shelf and rolls across the floor  coming to rest at a pair of highly polished jackboots.  Szpilman stifles a gasp. On the stairs, in silhouette, gazing down at him, the fig of a GERMAN CAPTAIN, the thumb of one hand caught in his  belt above his pistol.
(stern) Who the hell are you?
Szpilman just stares at him.
Who are you?
No response.
What the hell are you doing?
(barely audible, in  German) I was... I was trying to open this  tin.
Where do you live?
No response.
What's your work?
I am... I was a pianist.
A pianist.
He studies Szpilman for a moment, then with a nod orders  him to follow. Szpilman picks up the tin and follows.

Szpilman follows the German Captain through a double door hanging off its hinges, into a room with a broken table i the centre, what once was the dining room. And then throu another set of doors. The German Captain's boots echo.  They come into a spacious room. Faint moonlight filters  through the large windows. Fallen masonry and broken glas A couple of chairs. And a grand piano in the corner. The German Captain points at the piano.
Play.

Szpilman hesitates, then limps to the piano, puts down th tin, and opens the lid. He turns and drags one of the cha over and sits. The German Captain stands and watches. Szpilman glances surreptitiously at his hands, and then h plays Chopin. The German Captain listens, expressionless. The pale  moonlight shows him to be a handsome, elegant man.  Szpilman finishes playing. Silence. Somewhere, a cat mews. Distant burst of rifle fire. The German Captain stares at Szpilman. After a moment:
Are you hiding here?
Szpilman nods.
Jew?
Long pause. Szpilman just stares at him.
Where are you hiding?
(in German) In the attic.
Show me.
Szpilman hesitates, takes the tin and then shuffles past  the German Captain towards the door.

location: ATTIC AND LOFT AREA, RUINED VILLA

text: Szpilman and the German Captain enter. The German Captain takes out a flashlight, sees the ladde in place, leading up to the loft. Szpilman climbs the ladder, squeezes into the loft and  looks down at the German Captain, who shines his light on him.
Have you anything to eat?
Szpilman shows him the tin.
I'll bring you something.
He goes quickly, leaving Szpilman in darkness. Szpilman,  overcome by relief, can barely catch his breath.
The German Captain strides out of the villa, down the fro steps to a waiting car and a driver. He gets into the car The driver starts the engine and the car speeds off into  the night.
Szpilman hears the car's engine growing fainter. He start to tremble and then begins to cry. He weeps uncontrollabl

Much activity: officers coming and going, orderlies typin Officers king on field telephones. Desks, filing cabinets The German Captain, carrying a bulging shoulder bag, marc into a room just off the hall and goes to his desk just a an orderly drops papers in his in-tray. On the desk, ther a framed photograph of him nth a woman and two children.  German Captain glances at the papers, takes a pen, initia one or two and then goes.
The German Captain marches up the stairs purposefully, as if he's on urgent business.
The German Captain enters. He puts two fingers in his mou and whistles.
Open up.
After a moment, the trapdoor shifts and Szpilman looks  down. The German Captain takes a package from his shoulder bag  and throws it up into the loft. He turns to go.
Please.
The German Captain stops.
What's all that gunfire?
The Russians. On the other side of  the river. (Turns to leave,  stops; with a touch  of irony:) All you have to do is hang on for  a few more weeks.
He goes quickly. Szpilman opens the package, finds bread and marmalade.  Then he finds a tin-opener.

Snow. The sound of distant gunfire.  The Germans are evacuating the villa. Men carry out boxes filing cabinets, desks, papers and load them into trucks. They're careless, leaving a trail of debris. No sentries  now.

location: ATTIC AND LOFT AREA, RUINED VILLA

text: Szpilman, listening and shivering with cold. He hears the whistle. He opens the trapdoor to see the German Captain  in the attic, carrying a package.
Come down.
Szpilman descends.
What's happening?
We're getting out.
Szpilman faces the German Captain.
(in German) Are the Russians here?
Not yet.
He hands Szpilman the package. Szpilman opens it to find  inside several loaves of bread.
I don't know how to thank you.
Don't thank me. Thank God. It's  His will that we should survive.  Well. That's what we have to  believe.
Silence. Szpilman shivers with cold. The German Captain  takes off his coat and gives it to him.
What about you?
I've got another one.  Warmer. (brief pause) What will you do when it's all  over?
I'll play the piano again. On Polish  radio.
Tell me your name. I'll listen out  for you.
Szpilman.
Szpilman. (a crooked smile) Good name for a pianist.
Freezing weather. Empty streets. Then the sound of recorded music, as a car, with a  loudspeaker and a Polish national flag, comes into view,  the Polish national anthem blaring out from the speaker.
Szpilman, wearing the German Captain's coat and under the eiderdown, hears the strange sound of the music, which he recognises. He's astonished, puzzled. He comes to a decision and star to leave.
Cautiously, in his German military overcoat, Szpilman tro down the staircase into the empty hall.  He goes to the front door, opens it a crack and cautiousl goes out.
Szpilman looks around, hearing the car loudspeaker  indistinctly.
...German army! Polish soil  liberated!  Official!

His excitement grows and he walks out into the street.  He sees at one end soldiers serving soup from afield kitc to a group of people.  On the opposite side of the street, he sees a man and a  woman who have left the field kitchen. The man carries a  two-tiered canister. Szpilman rushes towards them, grabs hold of the man and  tries to kiss him. The man, totally bewildered, tries to  fight him off. The woman is terrified.
German! German!
She runs, yelling, towards the field kitchen. So does the man. Szpilman stands and stares, then sees one of the soldiers cock his rifle and fire at him. Szpilman runs, the firing continuing.
Szpilman bolts into the doorway of a ruined building. He  peers out to see Polish soldiers beginning to surround th ruined building, firing shots, lobbing in a grenade or  two.
(shouting) Stop, for God's sake, I beg you,  I'm Polish!
More shots and another grenade explosion.
Don't shoot! I'm Polish!
The Polish soldiers: Two of the officers stand near the  entrance, hearing Szpilman's shouts.
He's Polish!
(yelling) Come out with your hands up.
(obeying) Don't shoot! I'm Polish! Please,  please! I'm Polish!
Yes, he's Polish!
(as Szpilman  approaches') Why the fucking coat?
I'm cold.
The Polish officers confer briefly in whispers. Then:
Take him to headquarters.
And they march him off.

location: LONG COUNTRY LANE AND HOLDING CAMP

text: Spring. Idyllic.  A column of men and women stretching along the length of  the lane. A couple of horse-and-carts. One or two bicycle Some of the people wear concentration camp garb, others i tattered clothing.  Four men walk together and when they come to a narrow  junction, stop, seeing something  Behind barbed wire, German prisoners of war, guarded by  Russian soldiers. Desolate place. No shelters, no tents.  The POWs sit or lie on the ground, silent, broken,  shattered. The four men gaze at them. :
Look at them - bastards!
German fuckers!
I prayed for this, never thought  I'd see it.
The fourth man, ZYGMUNT LEDNICKI, approaches the barbed  wire.
Murderers! Assassins!  Look at you  now! You took everything I had!   Me, a musician! (wagging his finger  fiercely) You took my violin! You took my  soul!
He stands glowering at them, then sees a POW rise from a  group, wretched, shabby, unshaven. It's the German Captai uniform tattered, a wreck. He comes to the barbed wire.
(urgent) (in German) Do you happen to know another  musician, a Mr Szpilman? A pianist!  Polish radio?
Yes, of course, I know Szpilman.
(desperate) I helped Mr Szpilman when he was  in hiding. Tell him I'm here. Ask  him to help me...
A RUSSIAN GUARD, inside the compound, approaches, grabs  hold of the German Captain.
(to Lednicki, in  Russian) Hey! No talking to the prisoners.  Get away from there!
He drags the German Captain away from the wire.
(as he backs away,  calling) What's your name?
The German Captain is being bundled away by the guard, wh aims a kick at him. The German Captain shouts out his nam but it's unintelligible.
What?
The German Captain and the guard have disappeared. Lednic stands for a moment, then turns and goes.

Szpilman playing the piano. He looks something like his  former self, fairly well dressed and groomed.  He glances towards the glass booth and sees Lednicki with the technicians. He smiles. Lednicki nods, smiles back.
Szpilman and Lednicki looking around an empty field.
It was here, I'm certain of it.
It's not here now.
I shouted abuse at them, I'm not  proud of it, but that's what I  did, and, I'm certain, I stood  where you are now. There was barbed  wire, and this German came up to  me.
You didn't catch his name.
No. I'll ask at the factory. They  may know something.
Lednicki goes. Szpilman stands, looking around the empty field. He is  filled with sadness. He sits. He closes his eyes and put  his face to the sun.
IT WAS LATER DISCOVERED THAT THE NAME OF THE GERMAN OFFICER
ALL THAT IS KNOWN IS THAT HE DIED IN A SOVIET PRISONER-OF-WAR CAMP IN 1952. WLADYSLAW SZPILMAN CONTINUED TO LIVE IN WARSAW UNTIL HIS DEATH ON 6 JULY 2OOO. HE WAS EIGHTY-EIGHT YEARS OLD.
Szpilman plays Chopin's Piano Concerto No 1 with full  orchestra and conductor. He plays superbly. The music is  glorious.
